awd_titl_txt: RoL: FELS EAGER: Environmental drivers of intraspecific variation in animal behavior and consequences for ecosystem functions
awd_abstract_narration:
Differences in traits among species are widely understood to influence key processes that occur in ecosystems, such as the cycling of nutrients and transfer of energy within food webs. However, substantial variation in traits, such as behavior, also occurs among individuals within a single species. It is an important scientific challenge to understand whether variation in traits within species is also important for ecosystem processes. Behavioral traits are often the first to respond to changes in the environment, and it is now widely appreciated that many species exhibit critical behavioral differences both within and among populations. This project will test the novel hypothesis that within-population differences in the behavior of two widely distributed freshwater crayfish affect energy transfer and nutrient cycling. In addition, the project will evaluate whether behavioral traits that vary among crayfish populations are related to environmental characteristics, to predict how environmental change may influence the ecological impacts of these species. Crayfish often play a central role in stream ecosystems, and there is substantial variation in feeding behavior among crayfish populations, which is likely to influence their ecological impacts. This project is potentially transformative in considering whether behavioral variation within species is essential for predicting ecological processes. In addition, it will enhance the ability of researchers to predict the ecological consequences of human-induced changes to species' traits. The project will also provide outreach to educators and scientific training for multiple graduate and undergraduate students. 

The objectives of this project are to determine whether behavioral variation within crayfish species: (1) affects stream ecosystem functions and (2) is predictably associated with differences in local and regional environmental characteristics. This project will be accomplished using two crayfish species that inhabit streams across a latitudinal gradient from Wisconsin through Alabama and Tennessee. Specifically, in streams across each species' range, researchers will quantify stream metabolism (photosynthesis and respiration) in different habitats and measure local (resource availability, predation) and regional (climate) environmental variables. Researchers will also examine within-species differences in the behavior of crayfish collected from these streams using laboratory behavioral assays. Finally, researchers will use larger, semi-natural experiments to examine the effects of crayfish populations that differ in behavior on critical ecosystem functions including leaf litter decomposition, nutrient cycling, and ecosystem metabolism. This high-risk project spans levels of biological organization by connecting organismal behavior to larger, ecosystem-scale dynamics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
It is widely understood that the traits of a species regulate its ecological effects, and that the species present in an ecosystem can impact essential processes such as the cycling of nutrients and energy. However, substantial variation in traits, such as behavior, can also occur within a single species. Humans are rapidly altering the traits within species at a global scale through impacts such as habitat alteration. Therefore, it is critical to determine whether the variation in traits within species have ecological consequences at the ecosystem level. Behavioral traits are often the first to respond to changes in the environment, and it is now widely appreciated that many species exhibit critical behavioral differences both within and among populations. This project tested the novel hypothesis that among-population differences in the behavior of two widely distributed freshwater crayfish affect ecosystem processes in streams such as the breakdown of leaf litter and primary production and respiration in the water column. In addition, the project evaluated whether behavioral traits that vary among crayfish populations are related to environmental characteristics, to predict how environmental change may influence the ecological impacts of these species.

This research identified substantial among-population variation in behavioral traits including activity level, boldness, and feeding rate within two species of crayfish that are common in streams in the Midwest USA, rusty and virile crayfish. Further, the results suggest that these differences in behavioral traits had strong impacts on ecosystem processes in streams. In semi-natural controlled experiments, artificial streams with active crayfish had 200 to 400% higher rates of primary production and 40 to 100% higher rates of respiration in the water column than those with inactive crayfish of the same species. Further, artificial streams with shy crayfish had 20 to 30% higher rates of leaf litter breakdown than those with bold crayfish of the same species. Researchers also detected strong effects of rusty crayfish behavioral traits on these same ecosystem processes in natural streams. Thus, the data suggest that different populations of these species are having divergent impacts on the environment due to their behavioral traits. 

This research also identified strong associations between crayfish behavioral traits and environmental characteristics of streams (including summer water temperature, predation pressure, and food resources), suggesting that changes to these environmental characteristics may alter the behavioral traits of crayfish populations. Specifically, virile crayfish populations that were from streams with warmer water temperatures or lower predation pressure were bolder than those from streams with colder water temperatures or higher predation pressure. Virile crayfish populations from streams with more food resources (in the form of macroinvertebrates) also had higher foraging rates. Within rusty crayfish, behavioral traits were not well predicted by the environmental characteristics measured in this project. Many of the rusty crayfish populations sampled in this project were nonnative. Therefore, strong associations between environmental variables and behavioral traits may have been apparent within virile crayfish but not rusty crayfish because virile crayfish populations had more time to adapt to the local environment.

This project also provided scientific training in behavioral ecology and freshwater ecosystem ecology to one graduate student, four recent graduates, and twelve undergraduate students at the University of Florida, and one graduate student, one honors student and six undergraduate researchers at the Ohio State University. Researchers also led crayfish identification workshops for state agency scientists in Wisconsin and Florida to promote the correct identification of native and non-native crayfish. In addition, researchers led a virtual activity focused on behavioral research and overcoming observation bias for six classes of 3rd though 5th grade students through the Scientist in Every Florida School program. Finally, researchers created an outreach activity on invasive crayfish and clean water in local Ohio streams for the COSI, Center of Science and Industry, Science Festival. However, the activity was cancelled due to the COVID pandemic.

Overall, this project provides novel evidence that behavioral variation within a species can impact processes at the ecosystem level, suggesting that considering the drivers and consequences of behavioral variation within a species is important for understanding the ecological impacts of organisms.


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Lindsey S Reisinger
